DOC.HEAD: Premier Introduces Economic Recovery Plan
Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with premier introducing economic recovery plan, political changes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Premier Ante Markovic today proposed a new convertible currency unit in Yugoslavia as part of a sweeping reform plan to save the Communist nation from its worst economic crisis. About 160,000 workers staged a half-hour ``warning'' strike in the republic of Montenegro today to pressure the government into adopting urgent measures to contain hyperinflation, hovering at 2,000 percent. The strike coincided with the start of a three-day Parliament meeting, at which Markovic unveiled his proposals. A solution to the problems ``is not possible without a completely new economic and political system that would ensure economic efficiency and political democracy with full freedoms and human rights,'' Markovic said. Markovic said one new ``convertible dinar'' would be worth 10,000 old dinars. Yugoslavs should from now on be able to freely purchase foreign currencies with dinars in local banks, he said. The exchange rate would be fixed at seven dinars for one West German mark and remain unchanged until June 30, 1990, Markovic said. Until now, the dinar rate was adjusted daily compared to foreign currencies and has lost value rapidly as inflation has soared. One U.S. dollar would be worth 12 new dinars, instead of the current 120,000 dinars, Markovic said. The dinar was pegged to the West German mark because of its ``greatest stability'' on world money markets, Markovic said. He specified the changeover would take place Jan. 1, 1990, if Parliament approves the package. Markovic's government, which took over in March, has threatened to resign if the plan is rejected. Legislators have moved quickly to introduce market mechanisms as a way out of Yugoslavia's economic crisis, which includes a $17 billion foreign debt and 17 percent inflation. Yugoslavia's last re-evaluation of the dinar occurred in 1965. At today's meeting, Markovic also announced tight monetary and budgetary controls; free formation of interest rates which in the past have been set by the country's National Bank; and government control of prices on electricity, gasoline, rail transport, rents, postal services and medicines. The central bank would for the first time become ``fully autonomous'' in conducting monetary policies in accordance with market mechanisms and will no longer be allowed to print money in order to cover state deficits, Markovic said. The government also proposed to Parliament changes in the country's criminal code, including dropping the so-called ``verbal offenses'' under which thousands of people have been prosecuted for privately or publicly criticizing the Communist regime. The state Tanjug news agency said ``the last warning to the government'' was staged in the underdeveloped republic because its policy has ``brought a large part of Montenegro's population to the edge of famine and social misery.'' Similar strikes were expected to take place in the country's largest republic of Serbia on Wednesday and in the poorest region, Macedonia, on Thursday. The state-run trade union of Montenegro reportedly said in a proclamation that unless Markovic introduces urgent measures to raise living standards, ``a much longer general strike will ensue.''
